steps.title: It’s a medical condition triggered by swimming up too quickly.
steps.content: It’s a medical condition triggered by swimming up too quickly. When you go diving, you breathe compressed air that has a lot of nitrogen in it. Your body experiences pressure underwater, and the nitrogen filters through your body safely because of that excess pressure. But if you swim to the surface too quickly, the nitrogen won’t have time to dissipate into your bloodstream and it can start to form bubbles. Those bubbles lead to all kinds of problems that are collectively known as the bends. [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source The bends are also a risk if you’re in tunnel construction, mineral mining, or space exploration. It can also be a risk during depressurized flights. Luckily, these aren’t everyday occurrences and you’ll learn how to prevent the bends before you’re even allowed to do any of these things anyway. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, and ear or sinus pain.
steps.content: Symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, and ear or sinus pain. If you swim to the surface too quickly and you get the bends, you may have an odd pain in your ears, nose, or mouth. You may get itchy, and you’ll likely feel intense pain in your joints. You may also get extremely tired, run out of breath, get dizzy, or find it difficult to move. If you experience any of these symptoms after diving, see a doctor immediately. [4] X Research source In extreme cases, you may become paralyzed, lose control of your bladder, or pass out. [5] X Research source You may also have trouble seeing, or feel confused. [6] X Research source The bends are extremely dangerous if they aren’t treated, so do not hesitate to go to the emergency room if you suspect you may be experiencing the bends—even if your symptoms are minor. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Unfortunately, yes; the bends can lead to death if you don’t get help.
steps.content: Unfortunately, yes; the bends can lead to death if you don’t get help. If the nitrogen in your compressed air turns into bubbles and those bubbles reach your brain or lungs, it can lead to some life-threatening issues. You could have a stroke, seizure, or heart attack. Many people who get the bends experience paralysis, and they may have permanent brain, heart, or lung damage. The good news is that the treatment for the bends is extremely effective if you get help fast. [8] X Research source This is why it’s so important to get treatment ASAP. The faster treatment begins, the better your chances at getting better are. [9] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Use a dive table to take breaks on your way up to the surface.
steps.content: Use a dive table to take breaks on your way up to the surface. You can prevent the bends entirely by swimming up to the surface in sections and taking a short break in between each layer. How long you pause at each distance depends entirely on how deep you are and how long you’ve been diving. This is why people always bring a dive table with them underwater. A dive table is just a reference sheet containing all of the information you’ll need to know where to stop and for how long. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Dive tables are standardized—there aren’t different tables for different people. You should never go diving without one! If you’re new to diving, your instructor or partner should have a dive table with them. [11] X Trustworthy Source US Occupational Safety and Health Administration U.S. government agency responsible for setting and enforcing workplace safety standards Go to source You’ll also learn how to read a dive table if you’re earning your scuba certification! [12] X Research source As an extremely basic rule of thumb, you should stop roughly every 15 feet (4.6 m) for 5 minutes at a time. The slower you go, the safer it will be! Most dive computers have these tables built into the software. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Do not go diving if you have a hernia, heart defect, or asthma.
steps.content: Do not go diving if you have a hernia, heart defect, or asthma. Certain conditions may make you uniquely vulnerable to the bends. If you have an untreated hernia, diving may cause gas inside of your hernia to expand, which can contribute to the bends. People with heart defects and asthma are also uniquely susceptible to pressure changes, and you should not dive if you have any of these conditions. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source While it isn’t related to the bends, you should be mindful of diving if you have diabetes, since the pressure can cause your blood glucose levels to swing wildly.

steps.title: Skip the dive session if you have a cold, cough, or chest infection.
steps.content: Skip the dive session if you have a cold, cough, or chest infection. Colds, coughs, and chest issues can cause mucus buildups in your lungs and sinuses. The pressure your body experiences underwater can make these problems worse, and it will be harder to breathe comfortably as you swim back to the surface. Just to be safe, don’t dive if you’ve got any kind of breathing or sinus issue. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source If you have any trouble breathing, it will be harder for you to get the oxygen you need to filter out the nitrogen in time.

steps.title: Maintaining a healthy weight will minimize your risk.
steps.content: Maintaining a healthy weight will minimize your risk. People who are overweight or obese are actually more likely to get the bends. It’s thought that excess body fat makes it harder to get rid of all of the nitrogen. Maintaining a healthy BMI can help reduce your risk. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The most important thing you can do to prevent the bends is follow your dive table and take it slow on your way up. Maintaining a healthy BMI decreases your risk, but it isn’t a replacement for following safety protocols.

steps.title: Never go diving if you’ve been drinking alcohol.
steps.content: Never go diving if you’ve been drinking alcohol. Since alcohol increases your circulation and lowers blood pressure, it takes a lot longer for the nitrogen in your blood to filter out. This can render the diving table recommendations inadequate, and you’ll have a higher risk of running into decompression sickness if you’ve been drinking. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Swap your standard gas mixture out for EANx (Nitrox).
steps.content: Swap your standard gas mixture out for EANx (Nitrox). EANx, popularly known as Nitrox, contains a lower amount of nitrogen. This can dramatically decrease the odds you get the bends. The main downside of EANx is that it’s more expensive than the standard diving gas mixtures.

steps.title: Take extended breaks in between your dives.
steps.content: Take extended breaks in between your dives. The longer you can wait in between diving sessions, the more time your body will have to process all of the leftover nitrogen. If you’re going deeper than 10–20 feet (3.0–6.1 m) on daily dives, take at least one day off a week. This is especially important if you’re a diving instructor. Many cases of decompression sickness occur because instructors don’t take enough time off in between classes. It’s easy to skip breaks the more seasoned of a diver you become, but it’s super important to take long breaks in between sessions. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you ever do get the bends, wait at least 30 days after your recovery before diving again. [19] X Research source All of this will help minimize the odds you get the bends, but they aren’t replacements for taking decompression breaks while you’re swimming up to the surface. That’s the only way to 100% prevent the bends.

steps.title: Most often, the bends are a real concern after 30 feet (9.1 m).
steps.content: Most often, the bends are a real concern after 30 feet (9.1 m). The deeper you go, the more likely you are to run into the bends if you surface too quickly. Once you dive deeper than 30 feet (9.1 m), the bends become a serious potential problem. Do not ignore your dive tables, pay close attention to your pressure gauge, and time your decompression breaks carefully as you surface. [20] X Research source This is why diving tables typically start at 35 feet (11 m). If you’ve been swimming in water that’s 30–35 feet (9.1–10.7 m) deep but not further than that, just use the instructions for 35 feet (11 m) to surface safely.

steps.title: It’s rare, but the bends can occur at 10–20 feet (3.0–6.1 m).
steps.content: It’s rare, but the bends can occur at 10–20 feet (3.0–6.1 m). The bends generally aren’t a concern unless you go deeper than 30 feet (9.1 m), but the amount of time you spend in the water is a big factor here. If you’re diving in shallow water that’s deeper than 10 feet (3.0 m) for more than 30 minutes, you could potentially run into the bends if you surface too quickly. Swim up slowly and take a 5-minute break when you’re 5 feet (1.5 m) from the surface just to be safe if you’ve been in shallow water for a while. [21] X Research source [22] X Research source It’s exceptionally rare for the bends to occur in water shallower than 30 feet (9.1 m), so don’t panic if you haven’t been taking decompression breaks on the shallow dives you’ve completed in the past. If you’ve never had symptoms before, you have nothing to worry about.

steps.title: Yes, you can treat the bends with a few hours in a hyperbaric chamber.
steps.content: Yes, you can treat the bends with a few hours in a hyperbaric chamber. A hyperbaric chamber is a high-pressure container filled with 100% oxygen. Spending a few hours in one of these chambers will reverse the bends by turning those nitrogen bubbles back into liquid nitrogen, which is super easy for your body to process. It’s an exceptionally effective treatment, and most people with the bends are symptom-free after one treatment session. [23] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source It is extremely important that you get help as fast as possible if you get the bends. The longer those nitrogen bubbles have, the higher the odds that you run into permanent damage. Every hospital will be able to treat this. Even if they don’t have a large hyperbaric chamber, every hospital should at least have a monoplace. This is a hyperbaric apparatus designed for just one person. Since oxygen therapy is commonly used for a variety of injuries, burns, and infections, this isn’t particularly rare equipment in the medical world. [24] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: No, you must go to the emergency room if you think you have the bends.
steps.content: No, you must go to the emergency room if you think you have the bends. If untreated, the bends will lead to irreversible damage—even if your symptoms are minor and you’re feeling mostly fine. You may end up with permanent bladder dysfunction, sexual dysfunction, or muscle weakness. If the bubbles end up in your brain, you may get brain damage, have a stroke, or become paralyzed. [25] X Research source This isn’t the kind of thing you can leave untreated, so get help if you think you’re sick ASAP! [26] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source The absolute best-case scenario for untreated decompression sickness is that those nitrogen bubbles end up in your joints, which can lead to osteonecrosis or arthritis.

steps.title: Yes, you can’t fly for 24 hours after doing any diving.
steps.content: Yes, you can’t fly for 24 hours after doing any diving. Planes are typically fully pressurized, but if there’s even a minor pressure differential, nitrogen bubbles can develop if your body hasn’t had time to filter all of the nitrogen from your dive out through the bloodstream. As a result, you shouldn’t fly for at least one day after you’ve gone diving. It’s unlikely you’d get the bends on your flight, but it’s better to be safe than sorry! [27] X Research source
